Strongly depressing about cynical working life
Ken Loach has made yet another believable and engaging film about the struggles of working people in an increasingly cynical society. And have a LOT at heart about the new job market.
06 Nov 2019, 18:00 by Elisabeth Bie
Sorry We Missed You

Genre: Drama. Nationality: United Kingdom 2019. Director: Ken Loach. Screenplay: Paul Laverty. Actors: Kris Hitchen, Debbie Honeywood, Rhys Stone. Length: 1 hour 41 min. Age limit: 12 years. Cinema premiere: November 8th.

1 2 3 4 5 6
For 83 years, he has become British director Ken Loach. But his heart still beats as empathetic to the ever-weaker and more oppressed working class of British society. And his index finger is still full of resentment towards a political and economic system that ignores its ever-harder struggle for existence.
This time is the new labor market, with temporary jobs, under-staffing and cold demands for efficiency, which is illustrated in Loach's usual gray and social-realistic ways. Sober, with sparkling acting and tight, but slightly too staged script.
His own master, somehow
When Ricky gets the chance to become his own master as a franchisee in a transport and bidding company, the future after the financial crisis is saved. He thinks. Although wife Abbie has to sell the car she relies on in her stopwatch job as a home nurse to allow Ricky to get the car he is required to have in his new job. But slowly, but surely, the everyday life of the married couple and their two children appreciate that, up in the glue. What now?

The gold palm for British Ken Loach

As a cinematic experience, "Sorry we missed you" is not as strong as Loach's previous film "I" Daniel Blake. It is exhausting and depressing, gives little hope, and we do not come as close to the individuals.

Strong eye opener
But it is an extremely strong eye opener for the consequences of a working life without a safety net, both for individuals and society. Those who experience what the Turner family is experiencing cannot simply exit the cinema and shake off their sadness afterwards.
It is a very important insight, which we can more fortunately choose to use in so many kinds of small and big good ways.
